title: 114_s1989
content: The "Primary Care Enhancement Act of 2015" may be cited as the Act. It addresses the treatment of direct primary care service arrangements. The "Primary Care Enhancement Act of 2015" addresses the treatment of direct primary care service arrangements by amending the Internal Revenue Code to exclude such arrangements from being considered as health plans or insurance. The amendment excludes direct primary care service arrangements from being considered as insurance for tax purposes, effective for taxable years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3 amends the Internal Revenue Code to include periodic provider fees as medical care. This applies to taxable years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4 establishes the Medicare Primary Care Medical Home Demonstration Program. Section 1115A of the Social Security Act is amended to include a Primary Care Medical Home Model where qualified practices are reimbursed a periodic fee for services provided to individuals enrolled under part B of Medicare. Primary care medical home practices are reimbursed a periodic fee for services provided to individuals enrolled under part B of Medicare. Qualified direct primary care medical home practices are defined in the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. The Secretary establishes a periodic fee for qualified direct primary care medical home practices participating in the model under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. The fee cannot exceed twenty percent of the average per capita amount. The Secretary sets a periodic fee for qualified direct primary care medical home practices in the model under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, not to exceed twenty percent of the average per capita amount. The Secretary establishes a performance benchmark using ACO quality measures for direct primary care medical home practices participating in the model under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. Beginning in the second year of the model, adjustments are made based on performance. In the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act model, a primary care medical home practice that meets or exceeds the performance benchmark for the year will receive a 5 percent increase in the periodic fee paid for each enrolled individual. Practices that do not meet the performance benchmark will not receive this increase. The Secretary may terminate a qualified direct primary care medical home practice's participation in the model if the practice fails to meet the performance benchmark for two consecutive years. The participation of a qualified direct primary care medical home practice in the model may be terminated if it fails to meet performance benchmarks for two consecutive years. The practice must provide preventive care, wellness counseling, primary care, and coordinate care with specialty and hospital care. The direct primary care medical home practice must offer wellness counseling, primary care, coordinate care with specialty and hospital care, provide ongoing care appointments 7 days a week, secure e-mail and telephone consultation, and use a primary care provider panel size that supports the scope of services. The direct primary care medical home practice prioritizes enrolling dual eligible individuals. The term 'dual eligible individual' refers to someone enrolled in part B of title XVIII and described in section 1935(c)(6) of the Social Security Act. Care provided in a qualified direct primary care medical home practice is not considered insurance. Care provided in a qualified direct primary care medical home practice under this model is not considered insurance and is not subject to state insurance regulations. The practice must submit an annual report on the progress of enrolled individuals to the Secretary. The subsection requires the practice to submit an annual report to the Secretary on the progress of individuals with chronic conditions, including emergency room visits, hospitalizations, surgeries, specialist visits, and advanced radiology use. Additional areas determined appropriate by the Secretary may also be included in the report. The Secretary shall provide qualified direct primary care medical home practices with necessary patient data for clinical purposes and evaluation of the model. Providers currently opted out of Medicare may participate in a qualified direct primary care medical home practice under this model. Payment can be made for services provided to Medicare beneficiaries with whom the provider has a private contract. Fraud by participating physicians or practitioners is also addressed. The model allows providers opted out of Medicare to participate in a direct primary care practice with private contracts. Excluded physicians cannot join. The model will run for at least 3 years. The Secretary will conduct the model for a minimum of 3 years. If after the third year, a qualified direct primary care medical home practice meets the requirements, it can continue permanently as long as it continues to meet the criteria. After 3 years, a qualified direct primary care medical home practice can continue permanently if it meets requirements and if a majority of practices meet specified criteria, the model will be expanded nationwide. The Medicare Advantage Program may utilize direct primary care medical homes, with the potential for nationwide expansion if certain criteria are met. The Medicare Advantage Program allows Medicare Advantage organizations to contract with qualified direct primary care medical home practices to offer primary care services and share savings. The Medicare Advantage Program allows organizations to contract with qualified direct primary care medical home practices to offer primary care services and share savings. A qualified direct primary care medical home practice is defined as described in the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act.
